Dispute_Type: Leadership removal and replacement during a chaotic meeting
Legal_Issue: Validity of the November 3, 2002 election under band custom and principles of natural justice
Governing_Law: Band custom, principles of natural justice
Evidence_Assessment: Affidavits, historical election practices, lack of notice and secret ballot
Decision_Outcome: Election declared invalid; original councillors upheld
Burden_of_Proof: Applicants demonstrated violation of customs and fairness
Credibility_Factor: Small attendance, lack of procedural transparency
Legal_Rule: Elections must follow established customs or show broad consensus for change; natural justice requires fair procedures
Procedural_Issue: Lack of prior notice, advance nominations, secret ballots
Grounds_for_Claim: Violation of long-standing electoral customs and natural justice
Outcome_on_Merits: In favor of applicants; election voided
Judicial_Review_Outcome: Election declared invalid, original councillors reinstated
Review_Standard: Compliance with custom and natural justice
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Procedures were unfair and disenfranchised most members
Key_Evidence_Considered: Affidavits, historical election records, meeting attendance
Applicant_Challenge: To the validity of the November 3, 2002 election
Court_Result: Election is void; applicants and Norman Starr remain duly elected
Remedy_Requested: Declaration of election invalidity, reinstatement of original councillors
Outcome: Election declared void; financial accounts frozen
Legal_Provision: Principles of natural justice, customary electoral rules
Authority: Court jurisdiction over band elections under Canadian law
Outcome_of_Review: Election set aside, status quo restored
Pending_Relief_or_Application: Freezing of financial accounts pending resolution
Jurisdiction: Federal court or administrative tribunal with authority over First Nations governance
Governing_Rule: Election must adhere to established customs or demonstrate broad consensus for change
